partial_orders.reason: Edit 0 adds documentation stating that if `x` is a subtype of ndarray, the subtype will be preserved. Edit 1 adds a test that specifically verifies this behavior by testing that when a np.matrix (subtype of ndarray) is passed to pu.mapdomain, the result is also a np.matrix. Both edits reference the exact same function (mapdomain) and the test directly validates the documented behavior. The documentation change and corresponding test are bi-directional - either could be written first as both reference the same symbol and the test validates the exact behavior described in the documentation.

Edit 0 adds documentation stating that if `x` is a subtype of ndarray, the subtype will be preserved. Edit 1 adds a test that specifically verifies this behavior by testing that when a np.matrix (subtype of ndarray) is passed to pu.mapdomain, the result is also a np.matrix. Both edits reference the exact same function (mapdomain) and the test directly validates the documented behavior. The documentation change and corresponding test are bi-directional - either could be written first as both reference the same symbol and the test validates the exact behavior described in the documentation.

Edit 0 changes the implementation of the `mapdomain` function from using `as_series([x], trim=False)` to `np.asanyarray(x)`. Edit 1 adds test cases specifically for the `mapdomain` function, including tests for multidimensional arrays and subtype preservation. The test cases in edit 1 directly call `pu.mapdomain(x, dom1, dom2)` which is the exact same function being modified in edit 0. This creates a direct test-production code synchronization where the test assertions validate the behavior of the exact same method being changed. Both edits reference the same symbol (`mapdomain`) and the test code is designed to verify the new implementation behavior, making either edit a natural prompt for the other in a single development session.
